messages.subject: What to think on these tsuba?
messages.msgSnippet: Hi all, My second mantis tsuba ever was stripped off a shinto wakasashi that seemed to be in period mountings.  The blade was buffed and was eventually resold
messages.messageBody:
Hi all,

My second mantis tsuba ever was stripped off a shinto
wakasashi that seemed to be in period mountings. The
blade was buffed and was eventually resold minus the
tsuba. I just got this 2nd tsuba the other day. I am
attaching the photo, however, if Jim didn't allow
attachements I will post it. I was given attributions
of either ko shoami or akasaka mid edo. I know these
aren't of the highest quality, but I am seeking any
comments that can be made about them.

I don't neccesarily see the signs of casting that
normally are seen, ie bubbles around the seppa dai,
etc. However, barring the broken antanae (the 1st one
owned) and the wheel leg they match exactly. The back
pattern of the mantis appears to have some different
low relief detail carving crosshatch vs lines. I
think the one on the left (newest acquisition) might
need a really good cleaning which obscures some of it
plus it has some rust pitting here or there. Any
comments on them and or manufacture of them?

hopefully these pics won't take too long to load, I
just got high speed wireless internet access and I am
enjoying extremely fast download seconds!
Thanks,
Ken aka "the mantis dude"

__________________________________________________

messages.subject: Re: [nihonto] origami from Sept Chicago shinsa ????
messages.msgSnippet: Great news that Jim G is on the Kodogu shinsa team, I didn t know that. Well done Jim, congratulations Rich Turner ... [Non-text portions of this message have
messages.messageBody:
Great news that Jim G is on the Kodogu shinsa team, I didn't know that.
Well done Jim, congratulations

Rich Turner



Gordon Robson wrote:

> Hi all,
>
> I understand that everyone is impatient and that a wait of four months for
> those used to instant gratification is really, really long. However,
> please
> bear in mind that we are processing not only your half dozen
> kanteisho, but
> hundreds of kanteisho. They are now complete. We are working on a few
> problems such as missing photographs and getting Jim Gilbert's newly made
> stamp on the kodogu and koshirae papers. They will be sent to New York
> this
> month, which is a very fast turn around time for such a large project.
> They
> will be sent out individually from there, so I would expect everyone will
> have theirs sometime in February. I would also like to remind everyone
> that
> our kanteisho are all hand done by a group of calligraphy experts. And
> we do
> not use photographs for the nakago -- only hand done oshigata. This all
> takes time because we want to provide a good product for your investment.
> Please be patient a bit longer.
>
> Gordon
>
> -----Original Message-----
> From: KHolz64873@... [mailto:KHolz64873@...]
> Sent: Thursday, January 20, 2005 6:10 AM
> To: nihonto@yahoogroups.com

>
>
>
>

> Regards, Bruce
